trans-unit.source: Get Insights: Azure AD Password Management Reports | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get Insights: Azure AD Password Management Reports | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to use reports to get insight into Password Management operations in your organization.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to use reports to get insight into Password Management operations in your organization.

trans-unit.source: How to get operational insights with Password Management reports
trans-unit.target: How to get operational insights with Password Management reports

trans-unit.source: This section describes how you can use Azure Active Directory’s Password Management reports to view how users are using password reset and change in your organization.
trans-unit.target: This section describes how you can use Azure Active Directory’s Password Management reports to view how users are using password reset and change in your organization.

trans-unit.source: Password Management reports overview
trans-unit.target: Password Management reports overview

trans-unit.source: How to view Password Management reports
trans-unit.target: How to view Password Management reports

trans-unit.source: View password reset registration activity in your organization
trans-unit.target: View password reset registration activity in your organization

trans-unit.source: View password reset activity in your organization
trans-unit.target: View password reset activity in your organization

trans-unit.source: Overview of Password Management reports
trans-unit.target: Overview of Password Management reports

trans-unit.source: Once you deploy password reset, one of the most common next steps is to see how it is being used in your organization.
trans-unit.target: Once you deploy password reset, one of the most common next steps is to see how it is being used in your organization.

trans-unit.source: For example, you may want to get insight into how users are registering for password reset, or how many password resets have been done in the last few days.
trans-unit.target: For example, you may want to get insight into how users are registering for password reset, or how many password resets have been done in the last few days.

trans-unit.source: Here are some of the common questions that you will be able to answer with the Password Management reports that exist in the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com) today:
trans-unit.target: Here are some of the common questions that you will be able to answer with the Password Management reports that exist in the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com) today:

trans-unit.source: How many people have registered for password reset?
trans-unit.target: How many people have registered for password reset?

trans-unit.source: Who has registered for password reset?
trans-unit.target: Who has registered for password reset?

trans-unit.source: What data are people registering?
trans-unit.target: What data are people registering?

trans-unit.source: How many people reset their passwords in the last 7 days?
trans-unit.target: How many people reset their passwords in the last 7 days?

trans-unit.source: What are the most common methods users or admins use to reset their passwords?
trans-unit.target: What are the most common methods users or admins use to reset their passwords?

trans-unit.source: What are common issues users or admins face when attempting to use password reset?
trans-unit.target: What are common issues users or admins face when attempting to use password reset?

trans-unit.source: What admins are resetting their own passwords frequently?
trans-unit.target: What admins are resetting their own passwords frequently?

trans-unit.source: Is there any suspicious activity going on with password reset?
trans-unit.target: Is there any suspicious activity going on with password reset?

trans-unit.source: How to view Password Management reports
trans-unit.target: How to view Password Management reports

trans-unit.source: To find the Password Management reports, follow the steps below:
trans-unit.target: To find the Password Management reports, follow the steps below:

trans-unit.source: Click on the **Active Directory** extension in the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com).
trans-unit.target: Click on the **Active Directory** extension in the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com).

trans-unit.source: Select your directory from the list that appears in the portal.
trans-unit.target: Select your directory from the list that appears in the portal.

trans-unit.source: Click on the **Reports** tab.
trans-unit.target: Click on the **Reports** tab.

trans-unit.source: Look under the **Activity Logs** section.
trans-unit.target: Look under the **Activity Logs** section.

trans-unit.source: Select either the **Password reset activity** report or the **Password reset registration activity** report.
trans-unit.target: Select either the **Password reset activity** report or the **Password reset registration activity** report.

trans-unit.source: View password Reset registration activity
trans-unit.target: View password Reset registration activity

trans-unit.source: The password reset registration activity report shows all password reset registrations that have occurred in your organization.
trans-unit.target: The password reset registration activity report shows all password reset registrations that have occurred in your organization.

trans-unit.source: A password reset registration is displayed in this report for any user who has successfully registered authentication information at the password reset registration portal ([http://aka.ms/ssprsetup](http://aka.ms/ssprsetup)).
trans-unit.target: A password reset registration is displayed in this report for any user who has successfully registered authentication information at the password reset registration portal ([http://aka.ms/ssprsetup](http://aka.ms/ssprsetup)).

trans-unit.source: **Max time range**: 1 month
trans-unit.target: **Max time range**: 1 month

trans-unit.source: **Max number of rows**: unlimited
trans-unit.target: **Max number of rows**: unlimited

trans-unit.source: **Downloadable**: Yes, via CSV file
trans-unit.target: **Downloadable**: Yes, via CSV file

trans-unit.source: Description of report columns
trans-unit.target: Description of report columns

trans-unit.source: The following list explains each of the report columns in detail:
trans-unit.target: The following list explains each of the report columns in detail:

trans-unit.source: **User** – the user who attempted a password reset registration operation.
trans-unit.target: **User** – the user who attempted a password reset registration operation.

trans-unit.source: **Role** – the role of the user in the directory.
trans-unit.target: **Role** – the role of the user in the directory.

trans-unit.source: **Date and Time** – the date and time of the attempt.
trans-unit.target: **Date and Time** – the date and time of the attempt.

trans-unit.source: **Data Registered** – what authentication data the user provided during password reset registration.
trans-unit.target: **Data Registered** – what authentication data the user provided during password reset registration.

trans-unit.source: Description of report values
trans-unit.target: Description of report values

trans-unit.source: The following table describes the different values allowed for each column:
trans-unit.target: The following table describes the different values allowed for each column:

trans-unit.source: Column
trans-unit.target: Column

trans-unit.source: Allowed values and their meanings
trans-unit.target: Allowed values and their meanings

trans-unit.source: Data Registered
trans-unit.target: Data Registered

trans-unit.source: **Alternate Email** – user used alternate email or authentication email to authenticate
trans-unit.target: **Alternate Email** – user used alternate email or authentication email to authenticate

trans-unit.source: **Office Phone**– user used office phone to authenticate
trans-unit.target: **Office Phone**– user used office phone to authenticate

trans-unit.source: **Mobile Phone** - user used mobile phone or authentication phone to authenticate
trans-unit.target: **Mobile Phone** - user used mobile phone or authentication phone to authenticate

trans-unit.source: **Security Questions** – user used security questions to authenticate
trans-unit.target: **Security Questions** – user used security questions to authenticate

trans-unit.source: **Any combination of the above (e.g. Alternate Email + Mobile Phone)** – occurs when a 2 gate policy is specified and shows which two methods the user used to authentication his password reset request.
trans-unit.target: **Any combination of the above (e.g. Alternate Email + Mobile Phone)** – occurs when a 2 gate policy is specified and shows which two methods the user used to authentication his password reset request.

trans-unit.source: View password reset activity
trans-unit.target: View password reset activity

trans-unit.source: This report shows all password reset attempts that have occurred in your organization.
trans-unit.target: This report shows all password reset attempts that have occurred in your organization.

trans-unit.source: **Max time range**: 1 month
trans-unit.target: **Max time range**: 1 month

trans-unit.source: **Max number of rows**: unlimited
trans-unit.target: **Max number of rows**: unlimited

trans-unit.source: **Downloadable**: Yes, via CSV file
trans-unit.target: **Downloadable**: Yes, via CSV file

trans-unit.source: Description of report columns
trans-unit.target: Description of report columns

trans-unit.source: The following list explains each of the report columns in detail:
trans-unit.target: The following list explains each of the report columns in detail:

trans-unit.source: **User** – the user who attempted a password reset operation (based on the User ID field provided when the user comes to reset a password).
trans-unit.target: **User** – the user who attempted a password reset operation (based on the User ID field provided when the user comes to reset a password).

trans-unit.source: **Role** – the role of the user in the directory.
trans-unit.target: **Role** – the role of the user in the directory.

trans-unit.source: **Date and Time** – the date and time of the attempt.
trans-unit.target: **Date and Time** – the date and time of the attempt.

trans-unit.source: **Method(s) Used** – what authentication methods the user used for this reset operation.
trans-unit.target: **Method(s) Used** – what authentication methods the user used for this reset operation.

trans-unit.source: **Result** – the end result of the password reset operation.
trans-unit.target: **Result** – the end result of the password reset operation.

trans-unit.source: **Details** – the details of why the password reset resulted in the value it did.
trans-unit.target: **Details** – the details of why the password reset resulted in the value it did.

trans-unit.source: Also includes any mitigation steps you might take to resolve an unexpected error.
trans-unit.target: Also includes any mitigation steps you might take to resolve an unexpected error.

trans-unit.source: Description of report values
trans-unit.target: Description of report values

trans-unit.source: The following table describes the different values allowed for each column:
trans-unit.target: The following table describes the different values allowed for each column:

trans-unit.source: Column
trans-unit.target: Column

trans-unit.source: Allowed values and their meanings
trans-unit.target: Allowed values and their meanings

trans-unit.source: Methods Used
trans-unit.target: Methods Used

trans-unit.source: **Alternate Email** – user used alternate email or authentication email to authenticate
trans-unit.target: **Alternate Email** – user used alternate email or authentication email to authenticate

trans-unit.source: **Office Phone** – user used office phone to authenticate
trans-unit.target: **Office Phone** – user used office phone to authenticate

trans-unit.source: **Mobile Phone** – user used mobile phone or authentication phone to authenticate
trans-unit.target: **Mobile Phone** – user used mobile phone or authentication phone to authenticate

trans-unit.source: **Security Questions** – user used security questions to authenticate
trans-unit.target: **Security Questions** – user used security questions to authenticate

trans-unit.source: **Any combination of the above (e.g. Alternate Email + Mobile Phone)** – occurs when a 2 gate policy is specified and shows which two methods the user used to authentication his password reset request.
trans-unit.target: **Any combination of the above (e.g. Alternate Email + Mobile Phone)** – occurs when a 2 gate policy is specified and shows which two methods the user used to authentication his password reset request.

trans-unit.source: Result
trans-unit.target: Result

trans-unit.source: **Abandoned** – user started password reset but then stopped halfway through without completing
trans-unit.target: **Abandoned** – user started password reset but then stopped halfway through without completing

trans-unit.source: **Blocked** – user’s account was prevented to use password reset due to attempting to use the password reset page or a single password reset gate too many times in a 24 hour period
trans-unit.target: **Blocked** – user’s account was prevented to use password reset due to attempting to use the password reset page or a single password reset gate too many times in a 24 hour period

trans-unit.source: **Cancelled** – user started password reset but then clicked the cancel button to cancel the session part way through
trans-unit.target: **Cancelled** – user started password reset but then clicked the cancel button to cancel the session part way through

trans-unit.source: **Contacted Admin** – user had a problem during his session that he could not resolve, so the user clicked the “Contact your administrator” link instead of finishing the password reset flow
trans-unit.target: **Contacted Admin** – user had a problem during his session that he could not resolve, so the user clicked the “Contact your administrator” link instead of finishing the password reset flow

trans-unit.source: **Failed** – user was not able to reset a password, likely because the user was not configured to use the feature (e.g. no license, missing authentication info, password managed on-prem but writeback is off).
trans-unit.target: **Failed** – user was not able to reset a password, likely because the user was not configured to use the feature (e.g. no license, missing authentication info, password managed on-prem but writeback is off).

trans-unit.source: **Succeeded** – password reset was successful.
trans-unit.target: **Succeeded** – password reset was successful.

trans-unit.source: Details
trans-unit.target: Details

trans-unit.source: See table below
trans-unit.target: See table below

trans-unit.source: Allowed values for details column
trans-unit.target: Allowed values for details column
